questions.question: 1. What is the Fourier Transform of the Dirac delta function?

answers.d: An impulse in the frequency domain.

explanations.a: A sinc function is the Fourier Transform of a rectangular pulse.
explanations.b: A Gaussian function in the time domain transforms into another Gaussian.
explanations.c: The Fourier Transform of the Dirac delta function δ(t) is a constant function across all frequencies.

questions.question: 2. What is the significance of the duality property in the Fourier Transform?

answers.b: It allows the Fourier Transform of a signal to be obtained from its inverse.
answers.c: It relates time-domain multiplication to frequency-domain convolution.
answers.d: It explains how energy is conserved in the transform.

explanations.a: Convolution is simplified using the convolution property.
explanations.b: Duality enables symmetry between time and frequency domains for transforms.
explanations.c: This describes the convolution theorem, not duality.
explanations.d: Energy conservation is related to Parseval's theorem.

questions.question: 3. What type of signal corresponds to a sinc function in the frequency domain?

explanations.a: A Gaussian transforms into another Gaussian.
explanations.b: The step function has a complex frequency domain representation.
explanations.c: A rectangular pulse in time results in a sinc function in frequency.
explanations.d: A cosine wave has delta functions at its positive and negative frequencies.

questions.question: 4. Which of the following best describes the Fourier Transform of a time-limited signal?

answers.a: A time-limited signal has a band-limited Fourier Transform.
answers.b: The Fourier Transform is always infinite in duration.
answers.c: The Fourier Transform has the same duration as the signal.
answers.d: The Fourier Transform is finite only for periodic signals.

explanations.a: The Fourier Transform of a time-limited signal is not band-limited; it spreads over all frequencies.
explanations.b: This statement is correct as the Fourier Transform of a time-limited signal typically has infinite duration.
explanations.c: Fourier Transforms do not have the same duration as the signal.
explanations.d: Fourier Transforms apply to any signal, not just periodic ones.

questions.question: 5. What is the effect of multiplying a signal by a cosine wave in the time domain?

answers.a: It results in a band-pass filter effect.
answers.b: It shifts the signal's spectrum to a higher frequency.
answers.c: It convolves the signal with a sinc function in frequency.

explanations.a: This is incorrect; modulation does not create a band-pass effect directly.
explanations.b: Multiplying by a cosine modulates the signal, shifting its spectrum.
explanations.c: This applies to sampling, not modulation.

questions.question: 6. What happens when you double the frequency of a sinusoidal signal in the time domain?

answers.a: Its Fourier Transform shifts to the left.
answers.b: Its Fourier Transform shifts to higher frequencies.

explanations.a: Shifting left is incorrect; increasing frequency shifts the spectrum to higher frequencies.
explanations.b: Doubling the frequency moves the delta spikes in the Fourier domain farther apart.
explanations.c: Doubling frequency doesn't affect time duration.
explanations.d: It doesn’t make the signal more band-limited.

questions.question: 7. What is the consequence of sampling a signal below its Nyquist rate?

answers.d: The amplitude of the signal increases.

explanations.a: Sampling does not make the signal itself periodic, but its spectrum becomes periodic.
explanations.b: Frequency increase is not a direct consequence of undersampling.
explanations.c: Aliasing is the correct effect of undersampling — higher frequency content overlaps with lower frequencies.

questions.question: 8. What does the sampling theorem guarantee?

answers.a: Signals can be reconstructed exactly from samples if sampled below Nyquist rate.
answers.b: Signals must be periodic to be sampled correctly.
answers.c: Exact reconstruction is possible if sampling rate is greater than twice the highest frequency.

explanations.a: Sampling below Nyquist leads to aliasing, not perfect reconstruction.
explanations.b: Periodicity is not a requirement for sampling.
explanations.c: This is the core statement of the sampling theorem.
explanations.d: Aliasing can be avoided with proper sampling.

questions.question: 9. What happens in the frequency domain when two signals overlap in time?

explanations.a: Multiplication in time corresponds to convolution in frequency, not overlap.
explanations.b: Overlapping signals in time leads to addition of their frequency spectra.
explanations.c: Bandwidth is not compressed simply by time-domain overlap.
explanations.d: Cancellation depends on the phase, not just overlap.

questions.question: 10. How does aliasing appear in the frequency domain?

answers.a: As increased amplitude of the spectral components.
answers.b: As copies of the spectrum overlapping due to undersampling.
answers.d: As a shift of the whole spectrum to zero frequency.

explanations.b: Aliasing results in overlapping replicas of the spectrum in the frequency domain.
explanations.c: Aliasing is not a spike — it causes distortion.
explanations.d: Spectrum shifting to zero is not aliasing.
